newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Environmentalists say Cambodian logging persists.
newsitem.headline: Environmentalists say Cambodian logging persists.

text.p: Logging continues unabated in Cambodia despite a government directive banning all log exports from December 31, a British environmental group charged on Monday.

Global Witness, in a briefing paper titled "A Tug of War, the struggle to preserve Cambodia's forests," criticised the management of "quasi-legal" logging concessions, alleged continued government involvement in illegal logging and questioned the administration's commitment to reforming forestry policy.

The criticisms come soon after Minister of Environment Mok Mareth expressed concern over logging activities in Cambodian national parks, and they coincide with an International Monetary Fund (IMF) mission now reviewing Cambodia's forestry policy.
The IMF delegation is due to determine the fate of $40 million in loans due to Cambodia after the fund cancelled a $20 million payment last year over the logging issue.
Agriculture Minister Tao Seng Huor, speaking on Friday after meeting the IMF delegation, said all logging exports had ceased in accordance with a December 31 ban.
Co-Premier Hun Sen warned last Tuesday that Cambodia would have to resume cutting and selling logs if the IMF cut the loan as it would need the money to pay its civil servants.

"Although the RGC (Cambodian government) have taken some positive steps, illegal logging continues unabated: coupled with Hun Sen's ultimatum to the IMF one has to wonder if the RGC's commitment to forestry reform is beginning to slip," Charmian Gooch of Global Witness said in a statement.
